Recommended Treatment: Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and staging (including omentectomy and lymphadenectomy) followed by adjuvant carboplatin/paclitaxel chemotherapy, with consideration of external beam radiotherapy and vaginal brachytherapy per NCCN guidelines for stage IIIC2 uterine serous carcinoma.
Description: High-grade papillary serous carcinoma of the endometrium (4.5 cm) with full-thickness myometrial invasion, cervical stromal involvement, a small ovarian focus, and nodal metastases (pT3a N2 M0, FIGO IIIC2). Six of 26 pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes were positive.
Patient Notes: This report describes a high-grade cancer of the uterine lining called serous endometrial carcinoma that has spread into the muscle wall of the uterus, the cervix, a tiny area of the ovary, and nearby lymph nodes. The cancer is classified as stage IIIC2, which means it has reached the lymph nodes above the pelvis. Treatment will involve surgery to remove the uterus and ovaries, followed by chemotherapy (a combination of carboplatin and paclitaxel) and possibly targeted radiation to reduce the chance of the cancer returning.

verification.assessment: The extracted data are largely accurate and consistent with the report and NCCN guidance, but the nodal positivity count in the description is incorrect and should be revised. Additional molecular and immunohistochemical details would improve completeness.

cancer_organ_type.issues: Broadly labeled as “Uterine cancer”; more precise term is “Endometrial carcinoma”.

cancer_subtype.issues: Accurate as papillary serous carcinoma (uterine serous carcinoma).

pathologic_stage.issues: Appropriately recorded as pT3a N2 M0 (FIGO IIIC2).

recommended_treatment.issues: Follows NCCN guidelines for stage IIIC2 serous endometrial carcinoma; could also note recommended HER2 testing.

description.issues: Misstated the number of positive lymph nodes (extraction says 6 of 26, but report documents 5 positive nodes among 26).

patient_notes.issues: Clear and compassionate; accurately reflects extent of spread and planned treatment.
